did.abstract: The Dorothy Brier papers include professional papers related to her career as a social worker at Lenox Hill Hospital, New York, from 1971-1992. It includes unpublished papers, radio and tv scripts, and staff and community development program proposals. Also miscellaneous notes, clippings, and correspondence regarding social work in a health care setting.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections. Open with caveat: collection has not been fully processed and therefore may be somewhat difficult to use.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Dorothy Brier in 1995 and 2000. Accession numbers: 95S-39;00S-19. Earlier accessions are not described in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dorothy Brier received an A.B. from Radcliffe in 1951 and a MSS from Smith College School for Social Work in 1954. She was a caseworker and group therapist at the Community Service Society, New York City, 1954-1960; a social worker at the League School, Brooklyn, 1960-1961; and a supervisor, caseworker, and therapist at Youth Consultation Service (Dana House), NYC, 1961-1969. She also led numerous community projects, including work as a field instructor at the Community Service Society at Fordham University, NYC, 1969-1971, and as assistant director of education and programming at the Lenox Hill Hospital social work department, NYC, 1971-1991. She taught a continuing education course at the Smith School for Social Work, 1980, and she has published articles on social work in hospitals. Retired in 1992.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dorothy Brier papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00260, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dorothy Brier papers include professional papers related to her career since 1970 at Lenox Hill Hospital. It includes unpublished papers, radio and tv scripts, and staff and community development program proposals. Also miscellaneous notes, clippings, and correspondence regarding social work in a health care setting. Earlier accessions are not described in this finding aid.
